titlestmt.titleproper: Arcadio Díaz Quiñones Papers, circa 1944-2019 (bulk 1970-2012): Finding Aid

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid encoded in EAD 2002 by Techbooks, Cristela García-Spitz, and Diann Benti on April 20, 2007. Created from MARC record via MarcEdit and XSL stylesheets in 2007.
profiledesc.descrules: Finding aid content adheres to that prescribed by Describing Archives: A Content Standard.

did.abstract: The Arcadio Díaz Quiñones Papers consists chiefly of manuscripts and correspondence of the Puerto Rican professor of Spanish and Portuguese Languages and Cultures at Princeton University, Arcadio Díaz Quiñones (1940-), as well as a selection of manuscripts by others. The collection focuses on Puerto Rican and Cuban literature, but also provides insight into the literature and politics of other parts of Latin America.
did.physloc: This collection is stored onsite at Firestone Library. Box 19 is stored in special vault facilities.

bioghist.p: Arcadio Díaz Quiñones is Professor Emeritus of Spanish and Portuguese at Princeton University.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists chiefly of manuscripts and correspondence of Arcadio Díaz Quiñones. Some of the manuscripts of Díaz Quiñones are transcripts of unpublished interviews with writers. Included are the autograph and typescript manuscripts of his interviews with Luis Rafael Sánchez (partially published in the journal Sin Nombre [San Juan, P.R.], 1981), and Cintio Vitier (published as Cintio Vitier, la memoria integradora [San Juan, P.R.: Editorial Sin Nombre, 1987]). The bulk of the collection is made up of correspondence, predominantly between Díaz Quiñones and Puerto Rican and Cuban writers, but there are also letters from writers, artists, and scholars from other Latin American countries, Spain, and the United States, as well as from former students. Correspondents in the collection include Ricardo Piglia, Ángel Rama, Joseph Sommers, Rosario Ferré, Edwin Figueroa, José Luis González, Lorenzo Homar, René Marqués, Antonio Martorell, Ángel G. Quintero Rivera, Nilita Vientós Gastón, Ambrosio Fornet, Fina García Marruz, and Cintio Vitier. Notable as well is the correspondence with the Centro de Estudios de la Realidad Puertorriqueña (CEREP) and the Asociación Puertorriqueña de Profesores Universitarios (APPU). Also present is a small amount of printed materials, including event fliers and programs, and a copy of a map annotated by Argentine author Juan José Saer.

Furthermore, the collection contains a selection of works by others that were sent to Díaz Quiñones. These manuscripts include the writings of the Puerto Ricans Vanessa Droz, Rosario Ferré, Lorenzo Homar, José Luis González, René Marqués, and Luis Rafael Sánchez, and Cubans Víctor Fowler and Fina García Marruz.

The following standard abbreviations, or their variations, are used to identify materials in this collection: ALS = autograph letter signed, TLS = typed letter signed, ACS = autograph card signed, AMsS = autograph manuscript signed, and TMsS = typed manuscript signed.

arrangement.p: Material within each section is arranged in accession order.

accessrestrict.p: Material in Series 4, Box 19 is restricted until 2030.

userestrict.p: Single photocopies may be made for research purposes. No further photoduplication of copies of material in the collection can be made when Princeton University Library does not own the original. Inquiries regarding publishing material from the collection should be directed to RBSC Public Services staff at rbsc@princeton.edu. The library has no information on the status of literary rights in the collection and researchers are responsible for determining any questions of copyright.

At the request of Arcadio Díaz Quiñones, the correspondence and other documents by Reinaldo Funes, Ricardo Piglia, Luis Rafael Sánchez, Karl D. Uitti, and Hugo Vázquez is not available for any type of photoduplication.

bibliography.p: A manuscript found in draft form in the collection came to print in the following publication: Arcadio Díaz Quiñones, Cintio Vitier, la memoria integradora (San Juan, P.R.: Editorial Sin Nombre, 1987).

prefercite.p: Identification of specific item; Date (if known); Arcadio Díaz Quiñones Papers, Box and Folder Number; Special Collections, Princeton University Library.

processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Claire A. Johnston, Karla J. Vecchia and Danielle Ford in 1998.
Finding aid written by Claire A. Johnston, Karla J. Vecchia and Danielle Ford in 1998.
Finding aid updated by Armando Suárez in May 2019.

scopecontent.p: This series consists of manuscripts of interviews by Díaz Quiñones with different authors, such as José Luis González, Cintio Vitier, and Luis Rafael Sánchez, as well as several essays and literary reviews by Díaz Quiñones.

arrangement.p: This is arranged into subseries by acquisition number.

scopecontent.p: This series consists of both personal and professional correspondence sent to Díaz Quiñones by artists, scholars, and academic institutions. The sub-series within this series are organized by accession, and then alphabetically by correspondent. Two folders of unprocessed additional correspondence are located at the end of the "General" part of the accessions of 1998. At the end of the alphabetical listing of names in the 2004 accession, there are several folders containing Díaz Quiñones' correspondence and assorted materials on selected topics and various universities, as well as a small selection of memorabilia. Three folders of memorabilia, including conference and event flyers and articles, are likewise included at the end of the 2005 accession. In later accessions, the folders of memorabilia and those containing Díaz Quiñones' materials on selected topics have been placed in Series 4.

arrangement.p: Arranged into subseries by acquisition number.

phystech.p: For preservation reasons, original analog and digital media may not be read or played back in the reading room. Users may visually inspect physical media, but may not remove it from its enclosure. All analog audiovisual media must be digitized to preservation-quality standards prior to use. Patrons may request digital copies of original analog media, but will be responsible for the cost of digital conversion, payable in advance. Turn-around time for such requests will depend on the size and scope of the project. Requests should be directed to Public Services staff.

scopecontent.p: Contains paper by Toni Morrison Unspeakable Things Unspoken: The Afro-American Presence in American Literature. Dedicated to Díaz Quiñones and signed by author.

did.unittitle: Vázquez Zapata, Larissa (El nuevo día, Puerto Rico)

scopecontent.p: This series consists of manuscripts by various authors sent to Díaz Quiñones for criticism, along with some accompanying printed matter. Most of the individuals represented are major Puerto Rican writers and have a following elsewhere in Latin America. The sub-series within this series are organized by accession, with miscellaneous material located at the end.

arrangement.p: This is arranged into four subseries by acquisition number: AM 84-35, AM 84-35A, AM 84-25A, AM 1998-17, and AM 1998-31, and AM 2005-100.

scopecontent.p: Contiene una carta de Nelon Alvarez Febles y unos versos de un libro en proceso "Antología inevitable".
Contains a copy of "Literature and National Identity in Puerto Rico" by José Luis González, translated by Daniel Bladerston.

did.unittitle: Series 4: Subject Files, Memorabilia, and Other Materials

scopecontent.p: Consists of Díaz Quiñones' subject files, including symposiums, syllabi, essays and interviews, "trabajos," personal documents, and other materials, as well as a few files of memorabilia chiefly containing event fliers and programs. Also included is a poster and program from the University of Puerto Rico in Bayamón, and a copy of a map annotated by Juan José Saer.

arrangement.p: Materials are arranged as received by the repository.

scopecontent.p: Contains poster and program from the University of Puerto Rico in Bayamón related to a tribute for Arcadio Díaz Quiñones.

did.unittitle: Map annotated by Juan José Saer

scopecontent.p: Copy of a map of Sante Fe that Argentine author Juan José Saer annotated to show the spatial references of some of his works of fiction that he gifted to Diaz Quiñones.

accessrestrict.p: Material in Series 4, Box 19 is restricted until 2027.
